name: Maya - Chaac

sections.content:
Among the oldest and most widely worshipped deities of the Maya, Chaac is the god of rain, thunder,
                and lightning. With his distinctive long nose and jade ornaments, he wields a great lightning axe
                to split the clouds and release the waters that sustain all life. As the lord of agriculture and
                fertility, Chaac was essential to Maya survival, his favor bringing bountiful harvests and his
                anger devastating droughts. His goggle-eyed visage adorns countless temples across the Maya world.
sections.title: Description

subtitle: Chaahk- "Thunder" / "Lightning Strike"

periods.description: Ancient rain deity concept in early Maya culture
Central agricultural deity in lowland Maya civilization
Continued veneration, especially in cenote sacrifice traditions

calendarAssociations.haab: Storm season festivals tied to agricultural cycles

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
